review:
This is a really good and fun game, its an excellent introduction to electrical circuits and logic gates around defusing a bomb.  The steps of each section increase in complexity and there is a real sense of satisfaction in finding the solution.  

However there is one major gripe, sometimes the completion banner over lays the circuits so i could'nt work out why what i had done worked and had to repeat the process multiple times to work it out.  There are also multiple ways of achieving the correct outcome with the more complex circuits, and an explanation at the end would be nice to complete the learning experience.

It could do with more examples to play, as others have suggested, perhaps combining the individual sections into more complex circuits.  I would recommend Turing complete if you want more of this kind of logic game.

review:
I studied EE in college about *checks* 20 YEARS AGO?  Oh God I'm old.

Anyway, this game brings back joyful memories of sitting in a lab at 10:30 at night building circuits for labs.

Or in this case, un-building circuits for labs.  

This is definitely a game I did better on as I woke up.  The first time you blow yourself up you'll be awake.  Trust me.  I like how the game introduces new components gradually, but always incorporates older ones as you go.  Sometimes I get a little annoyed when some of the wire traces are hidden or tough to track, but that really doesn't happen often.  More often than not, I'll blow myself up because I forgot to trace a wire back to the power source before I flicked a switch.  Good times.

But overall the game is super forgiving - they understand this is... you know... a GAME.  You're meant to have fun.  And you will!  My only complaint is that I finished it and really want more puzzles.  I'd be willing to pay additional monies for additional puzzles in fact.

*HINT:  GIMME SOME DLC

Bomb Squad Academy est un petit jeu plutôt sympa qui vous met devant des bombes à désamorcer.

Toutefois, la durée de vie déjà relativement courte de base, se réduit à quasiment rien si comme moi vous êtes du métier. De plus, on regrettera l'absence d'un éditeur pour créer et partager nos propres niveaux. J'ai apprécié l'heure et demi passée dessus, mais clairement que ça ne sera pas un jeu auquel je rejouerai.

review:
EDIT: Note, this game has no Trading Cards despite the store page saying so. Check the market place to confirm whether this is still the case.

Bomb Squad Academy is a pretty well-done, though short, logic puzzler with the backdrop of defusing bombs. Every level is a lesson about a circuit component or a bomb to be defused.  The number of levels is decent with slowly increasing difficulty such that the game avoids becoming tiresome or annoying or overwhelming. You interact with the mouse cursor only which works well, using a mousepad could prove difficult at times. Graphics are more than adequate and the music is relaxing when not interspersed with the timer countdown beeps (can be turned off in the options). You should be able to complete the whole game in 90 to 120 minutes.

+ Nice graphics
+ Relaxed background music
+ Logical puzzles
+ Well put together
0 Short-ish, engaging but not exhausting

While the shortness of the game would usually undercut the reasonability of the game's price point of 5 Euros, its polish and well-put-together-ness make that a fair trade. Bomb Squad Academy is an easy recommendation for puzzle friends.

review:
Final score: Eh. For $5, it's a fun little game. I wouldn't nominate it for Most Gripping Game I've Ever Played, but for $5? It's a nice ~2-3 hours. (I just figure, it costs more to see a 2-hr movie, so win-win.)

Basically, it's just what it looks like: learn how the circuitry works. Learn what sets off the bombs. Load level... Ack! You've got 1-2 minutes to scan the circuit board attached to the time bomb. Now you've got to decide which wires to clip, which switches to flip, what buttons to press, etc. If you can defuse the bomb in the given time, hooray, everyone is saved. If you screw up, the screen turns white and you hear an explosion. You're dead!

It's not the most challenging game I've ever played, but they're fun little puzzles, and it really does give you that kind of "CLIP THE BLUE WIRE! NOT THE GREEN ONE!" feel of defusing a bomb. UI is pretty intuitive, instructions are pretty thorough and clear. There aren't zillions of levels but there are plenty.

Overall? If I had to buy this game again just for the cheap 3 hour thrill, I would.

Oh, and the best ever - "This bomb doesn't look very safe..." LOL really?

review:
O jogo em si tem muito potencial.
É como um "Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes" mas com uma questão de circuitos lógicos.

Mas como eu disse, com muito potencial, mas não usado. O jogo em si é curto, ele parece um imenso tutorial das funcionalidades do jogo, que você fica esperando para poder vir o resto do jogo, mas ele não vem, simplesmente acaba sem nada para completar o jogo, como um sistema de desenvolvimento de bombas ou um modo campanha.

Sobre a jogabilidade não há muito o que comentar, tirando o funcionamento do tempo no jogo, mas bombas são muito rápidas, algo como 1 ou 2 minutos no máximo. Você não consegue pensar racionalmente no jogo, é como pensar em 50% da bomba e no resto chutar pra ter a sorte de não explodir. Não há tempo para pensar e no final ter a sensação de você sentir-se inteligente por ter realizado algo difícil. Isso é muito frustante!

E como o jogo usa de sistemas simples de lógica, poderia haver uma utilização educacional com ele, mas eu que possuía conhecimento prévio sobre, já me frustei com o minúsculo tempo. Não consigo imaginar a frustração de alguém que estaria vendo isso pela primeira vez 

Eu paguei algo como quatro reais por causa de uma promoção, não acho que valha a pena isso. Se esses pontos fossem melhorados, e o jogo atualizado, seria uma compra certa, mas como ele não é atualizado a tempos. Sou obrigado a pedir devolução.

review:
ゲームの概要
コードの切断、AND回路やXOR回路、スイッチ、クロックなどの基本的な組み合わせからなる爆弾を
ぎりぎりの制限時間内で解除するゲームです
段階を踏んでいくので論理回路わからない人でも大丈夫

日本語サポートなしについて
英語自体は中学英語レベルで簡単なので問題にはならないと思います
自分でテキストを進めるタイプなので意味不明なら検索して読めばいいですね

クリア後感想
全体的に難易度は低めです
制限時間内に解けない場合でも、再挑戦するかスクショしてじっくり考えればいいので全問解けると思います
私はのんびりやってクリアまで2時間ほどだったので、ボリューム不足は確かに感じますが非常に面白いゲームだったと思います
制限時間に急かされながら爆弾を解除する爆弾処理班の気持ちを味わいたいならおすすめです

review:
It's a sequence of circuits. The game introduces you to a component and then you are facing a number of circuits with all thus far known components with increasing difficulty.

The gui is nice looking and the controls responsive. Since there is a limit on how much interactivity you can have with a given component (you can cut wires, turn knobs and push buttons), some circuits were completed without me fully comprehending the mechanics of it.

Strictly linear and the total amount of content is not too great. It would be a nice minigame within another game.

It, is however, a straight up game with little pretense. It will keep you entertained for some hours and you can easily sit down someone else who wants try.

It could use a designer mode and use the steam functionality to share bombs.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971401741', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1555549697}
review:
This is easily the best horror game I've ever played.

I know this doesn't look like a horror game, but honestly: Bomb Squad Academy has made me flinch more than any horror game I've ever played, no matter how loaded with jump scares it may have been. Every time I flip a switch, cut a wire, press a button or do anything that involves a live circuit, I'm a moment away from a spasm of 'OH ****' jolting through my body as the screen goes white and the explosion plays.

It's fantastic.

Beyond that, the game is beautifully designed, the concept just-close-enough to real life circuit board tinkering (in the most basic way, leaving out a lot of important stuff - I was disappointed at the lack of an actual full circuit, but hey). I bought it at the 'full price' of 4.99, and even if I suspect it's going to be short, I feel like it's money well spent.

I would happily buy DLC for this game that includes additional circuit concepts, puzzles, and more opportunities for me to twitch in momentary shock like a lab rat who isn't in the "control" group.

Good stuff, solid stuff, and keep making games guy, this one is pretty great.

review:
I'd LOVE to recomend this game, but I jsut can't, it's far far too expesnive and frankly I feel slightly cheated by it's price, as it is oh soo very short. 

Short games aren't bad, but they're not worth the the cost of 5p per min, in comparason to comparbably priced offerings, its just too much for a game like this.

It's a lovely lovely game, but it's a wordsearch not the times crossword, and isn't long or challanging enough to justify it's price.

The worst part is for double the dev time, it would have been very easy to impliment a endless mode with precedurally generated bombs basicly forever, as the computer only needs to follow 4 rules (If det is powered hit player lose, if disarm is powered palyer win, if time run out on intergrated detonator palyer lose, battery must be able to power all eliments)

Beyond that the computer only needs to drop a random path eliment and that's compatable with a solution. 

That's it, So the lack of an endless mode is increadbly disapointing. 

What is there is polished, and baby's first electronics project.  

But at £5 I cannot recomend in the face of steams other options and offerings.

I mean thats  book, audiobook, or film price there are better value propstion just here on steam. 

That said I enioyed every miniute of the game, but I could have called my best friend and been even happier, and sadly everything is relitive.

Wait for a sale.

Sorry Systemic, you tried, better luck next time. <3

UPDATE: the game's levels number have reportedly doubled since 28th of december, making it a relivtely higher value propostion, but still quite steep at around 2p a minitue. 

That said it's really nice the game has been updated for free. 

Hopefully if you're really into bomb disposasl this will increase the value.

However, it's still a one and done game, there is no replayablity other than as a repeat which is true of all things. 

I sstill hope for an endless mdoew or level editor.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997610474', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1529786933}
review:
Bomb Squad Academy is really a tutorial masqurading as a game.  So if you want to see how tutorials should be done then it's probably worth buying just to review it as a tutorial.  Otherwise ... your mileage may defintely very.  I picked it up in a steam sale; so by the time I've made a few people play it (it is a pleasant diversion) I'll have had my moneys worth.

Overall I've given this game a thumbs up because it is ultimately well done; and apart from the single issue the first time I started it I didn't have any problems with it.  With a level editor and a proper campaign this game would be awesome.  As it is, it's just "OK".

[b]The good:[/b]
[list]
[*]The simplified electrical concepts they use are well implemented and consistent.  And clear.  From an in-game UI point of view it's very well done.
[*]Each new concept is explained clearly with simple examples followed by more complex ones.
[*]The difficulty is graded very nicely.
[*]The puzzle elements are neat; and there are enough of them to be intreresting.
[*]When I got to the end I wanted more (it is an engaging game)
[/list]

[b]The bad:[/b]
[list]

review:
[h1] Bomb Squad Academy – симулятор сапёра от Systemic Games [/h1]

Bomb Squad Academy был выпущен 28 марта 2017 года ребятами из Systemic Games. Цена на этот продукт составляет 129 рублей в России и 2.99$ в странах СНГ.

[list]

[*] В Bomb Squad Academy мы будем исполнять роль будущего сапёра, который должен пройти сначала Академию Сапёров. Игра представляет из себя что-то типа головоломки с целью обезвредить бомбу. Нам дают бомбу, дают указания и мы должны с этими подсказками справится с бомбой. 

Разнообразие бомб есть, но не настолько много сколько хотелось бы. Самый главный минус данной игры – её продолжительность. Игра выполнена шикарно, арт замечательный, но прохождение всей игры займёт максимум час, а это ужасно мало. Вы не успеете влиться в роль сапёра как игра закончится. Разработчик обещает обновление, но пока его не видно.

[*] Бомбы выглядят замечательно. Это не 3D, но зато красиво нарисованная 2D схема бомбы. Оценить всю графику вы можете сами.

[/list]

Вердикт:[i] нереально интересная, продуманная игра, но нереально короткая. К сожалению её цена всё же немного больше продолжительности её геймплея. Советую покупать всем, но желательно со скидкой больше 15%. [/i]

Оценка:[b] 7.5/10[/b]. Очень годно – очень коротко.

author: {'steamid': '76561198280424024', 'num_games_owned': 896, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1553914167}
review:
This positive review is contingent on whether or not the developer ends up making more content (workshop integration would be the best) and reading the updates it sounds like that is planned, so positive review it is.

I love logic games, Zachtronic games being some of the best (Spacechem, Shenzen I/O, Infinifactory, etc), and this game has the potential to sit right up there with some of them...if there were more to it. I played through the whole game in 50 minutes.

But everyone talks about that so let me tell you what I love about this game.

Now, normally I really hate adding pressure to puzzles. It feels like an unnecessary addition to what, in my mind, should be a relaxing experience. But the way timers are used in this game is great, and I feel it really added something I haven't seen in other logic games. Multiple timers, timers that do different things, timers that play against each other, timers that you need to manipulate in different orders and different ways - it's just great. And if you are of a nervous disposition you can always just set off the bomb and study the circuit at your leisure. You can even still interact with the components on the board after the bomb goes off. I'm really glad that feature is in there even though I didn't take advantage of it much. I did reset a few bombs because I knew I was going to run out of time, but overall I actually really enjoyed playing against the clock, and that's about the highest praise I can give for a puzzle game that adds stress as a main element.

So basically, yes, this game is a bit overpriced for the play time, but the developer sounds like they want to continue with it, which I would love to see, so if you want to support the game I'd say go ahead and buy it. It has a lot of potential.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030922928', 'num_games_owned': 2586, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1498320042}
review:
One caveat: It's super short, so watch the price. Steam tells me I have 1.5 hours in this game, and 38 minutes of that I was on the phone and didn't bother to shut the game down, and I've played through completely. So it'll take you around an hour if you are somewhat experienced in logic puzzles, probably up to two if you aren't - the levels are very short (there is usually a one- or two-minute timer), and success or failure are often pretty much instant.

What is this game about? It's a logic puzzle game. There's sources of energy and lines on which the energy travels, there's components on those lines, such as switches, logic gates (AND, OR, XOR) and some others, that will change on which lines the energy travels or doesn't. The goal is to either get the energy to certain endpoints (often multiple ones, at the same time) or to cut an already existing energy line, all while avoiding to supply energy to specific other endpoints.

Namely, for most levels, there's a timer with detonator, featuring one endpoint for power which is already supplied by default, one to three "disarm" endpoints that have to be simultaneously supplied with energy to work, and one "detonator" endpoint, supplying which will mean instant defeat. A few levels are introduction levels, which only serve to show off how a part works, and the remainder - slightly more than a handful, really - are the most interesting ones, featuring clocks and detonators as separate parts, with the goal being either to cut power to the clock, to the detonator, or to cut the connection between the power output of the clock (that goes active once the clock hits 00:00) and the detonator input of the detonator.

I don't want to spoil too much, but there's levels with traps, less-than-obvious solutions and some with a simple fix to a very complex problem. It's great fun, if you like logic games, I just wish there were more levels.

review:
Если вы хотите казуальный пазл - это не плохой выбор. В ином случае не стоит тратить время. 
По окончанию игры кажеться что ты всего лишь прошёл обучение. Хоть последнее задание и кажется интересным, понимаешь, что оно могло быть намного лучше. 
В целом, игра была бы хорошей, если бы разработчики не решили делать [b]простой[/b] пазл.  Ведь в этом и суть пазлов - напрячь мозги. Но Bomb Squad Academy оказывается слишком интуитивным. Судя по всему идея была компенсировать это ограниченным временем, но оно ощущается только на первой попытке, ведь на второй ты уже знаешь как решить задачу.
Конечно появление редактора могло бы решить эти проблемы, но его нет.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099013029', 'num_games_owned': 633, 'num_reviews': 184, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1492458624}
review:
[b]Bomb Squad Academy 3/5:[/b] Titul z ranku "[i]babo raď[/i]". Na jedné straně jde o skvostně uchopený nápad formou škola hrou, kdy vás to nenáročnou, poučnou, atraktivní a zábavnou formou naučí základům elektroniky a jejích obvodů skrze jednotlivé blbovzdorně srozumitelné kroky/puzzly, které vám dají dostatek prostoru pro vyblbnutí se všemi těmi spínači, bateriemi, tlačítky, hradly apod.

 Na druhou stranu to i při šnečím tempu vašich mozkových závitů vystačí na ani ne hodinu a půl zábavy. A to více než hodina z toho je ve své podstatě tutoriálem a samotné regulérní puzzly tedy vystačí sotva na dvacet minut. Navíc i na tak malém prostoru se záhy začne zajídat otřesná kolovrátková hudební stopa; naštěstí se dá vypnout.

 Jakkoli to tedy lze spíše doporučit, tak je dobré si předně ujasnit/přizpůsobit svá očekávání. Pokud to budete brát především jako vhled do základů elektroniky a až v druhé řadě jako logickou hru či se spolehnete na to, že tvůrce bude do hry nadále pravidelně přidávat obsah ve velkém, tak není proč to nedoporučit. Pokud do toho však jdete s vidinou atraktivního námětu a vděčného puzzle potenciálu (slibující nejprve detailní prostudování zapojení v časovém presu a následné úpravy obvodu pro jeho přehrazení nebo odpojení), tak bych se tomu spíše vyhnul. Což je škoda, protože v tom je na každé obrazovce znát nesporný potenciál na nejeden zapeklitý puzzle. Bohužel je to potenciál pouze tušený, ovšem do praxe nepřevedený; resp. terminologií hry... Nespájený.

author: {'steamid': '76561198280371208', 'num_games_owned': 838, 'num_reviews': 272, 'playtime_forever': 114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 114, 'last_played': 1492093067}
review:
I guess you didn't need that arm after all

At Bomb Squad Academy, learn how to defuse bombs as you go level by level. Your instructor being very positive and eager to teach you the works of all the different concepts separated by eight different chapters. You'll be graduating in no time.

With the goal for players to understand how to defuse bombs, at least in-game, is very important that you nail a tutorial or that it can be understood by most of the players. Sometimes this will come before and hope that it can be remembered throughout the game or be optional if the player does not want to play or read through it. Bomb Squad Academy takes a different approach. The first thing you do in a chapter is tutorial levels in a school like way. This works well with how it was tackled. You are immediately introduced to this happy teacher showing you the ropes. Each on a tutorial circuit board, you are able to click, turn, or cut with no way to fail as it is not attached to a bomb. It doesn't try Backing off at the right time so you can prove that you learned that certain concept. I never thought there was too much tutorial bombs in a row and understood everything after. There was one that I did have to go back and redo, but it was due to a simple misunderstanding of a component.

As you pass the tutorials, the real thing is presented to you. Each level starts with the cheery teacher encouraging you before the bomb is revealed. The music changes to a tense theme as you try to complete a bomb before the timer goes out. All you have to do is either take away the power, or deactivate it by lighting up the disarming areas. The ticking of the timer staying in the back of your mind as you constantly look over as you try to deactivate it. Having to look over where the power will go and directing it's path with switches and dials. This is of course complicated by other components to trick you up such as wires directing power to other areas or AND and OR gates standing in your way. As each bomb uses logic and each board is constructed carefully, it does not seem like it was unfair. Pushing and cutting at random is not the way to go, especially when dealing with the be complicated ones.

You are mostly left alone with these bombs with the occasional notes to offer subtle hints such as "Closed Loop" or to give some humor. Let the timer go out and you are dead. Redirect the power to the detonate area and you are dead. There is not any consequences as you do get to start over, but there is a loud bang and a white light to symbolize an explosion. Your instructor also steps in with a dark but witty sayings after, "Too bad, you killed yourself, and everyone", bring the teaching setting further. The upside is that you do get a chance to see how you messed it up. Letting you not make the mistake again and plan for what you will do next.

What is interesting is how there are multiple designs for bombs. Simple ones looks like it's on a wrapped and duct tapped item while others have more of a outwards appearance of cylinders being together. Whether it be two, a few stuck together, or what suspiciously looks like a dynamite bomb. As the game acts like it is a school, it is cool to see that it brings in different designs to prepare the student to see when they do a real bomb.

The game will generally take at least over an hour to complete as it is easy most of the time. But the developer has said there are more things to come. More components are being thought up to put into the game. A circuit board editor is going to be worked on. Letting the players make workshop bombs and letting the developer make more boards faster. A random generator is also being thought up and trying to see if the feeling of a carefully constructed game can stay true. This is very encouraging to see how the developer wants to try and tackle hard goals and gives a lot of potential to Bomb Squad Academy.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
+ Great way to show players how each component works with separating tutorials
+ The school vibe is handled well and persists throughout
+ The logic behind each is understandable to the player no matter how hard

- Can be too short for some to consider

Bomb Squad Academy is about defusing bombs by going through a logic puzzle. The way it keeps this learning area is great and works well in teaching the player. Giving a sense of urgency as each bomb has a timer ticking down as you try to deactivate it. However as the content can be finished in one to two hours, this can turn people away despite how polished and great this game is. There is a lot of potential for more content to be added to an already great game. It may even teach you something about electronics no matter how simplified it presents this. You can download the [url=https://systemic-games.itch.io/bomb-squad-academy]demo[/url] here if you want to try it out before deciding to buy as well.

review:
Beaucoup, beaucoup trop court...

Le principe est bien pensé et assez fun, la difficulté est assez bien dosée (les puzzles ne sont pas très durs en soi, mais la contrainte de temps suffit à mettre beaucoup de pression) et le jeu a le mérite de pouvoir faire découvrir quelques notions d'électronique à  certains, mais le contenu est vraiment trop limité pour 7€ : J'ai du boucler le jeu en une heure environ et il n'y a aucune rejouabilité ensuite. Donc, même si j'ai passé une très bonne heure, je peux difficilement laisser une évaluation positive à ce jeu, quand on peut, par exemple, trouver Mini Metro pour 10€ ou The Witness pour 37€... Le rapport durée de vie/prix n'est juste pas raisonnable.

Il faudrait absolument ajouter à ce jeu un éditeur de bombes pour laisser la communauté enrichir le contenu. Si cela finit par voir le jour, je repasserai mon évaluation en positive.

Je le recommande néanmoins à tous les amateurs de puzzles si le jeu tombe à moins de 3€ pendant des soldes.

review:
Muy buena idea de juego aunque no implementada todo lo bien que se podría. 

Se trata de un conjunto de puzzles lógicos puestos en forma de placas de circuitos con puertas OR, AND, XOR, condensadores, timers, etc  como parte de las bombas a desactivar.

Se echan en falta más puzzles lógicos ya que apenas tiene una hora y media de juego. Además algunos puzzles no suponen un reto ya que se sacan más que nada por la falta de componentes con los que interactual. Si a eso le sumamos que no hay muchos...

Es divertido y una buena idea pero quizá sea caro para el contenido que trae.

review:
Rien à ajouter aux commentaires précédents : l'idée est excellente, les mécaniques réalistes sont très bien employées, mais l'heure de jeu nécessaire pour faire le tour de tout le contenu du jeu apparaît comme un simple tutoriel. Le pire, c'est qu'avec un simple éditeur de bombes et l'intégration Steam Workshop, la communauté ferait probablement le gros du travail toute seule. Malheureusement, aucun outil pour créer ses propres tableaux n'est fourni.

Un gâchis.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001967054', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 53, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1527318836}
review:
Great game, but not enough content for its price (about one hour of play time)

Cannot recommend unless either more levels are added, or alternatively a level editor / workshop integration to let the community make up for the lack of content.

It falls into the common trap of indie puzzle games where they introduce a new component but then do not make use of it and proceed to introducing the next component. There are only one or two non-tutorial levels for each introduced component, usually not even very challenging. This is very sad because there is a lot of potential in making challing puzzles with early components by just throwing more components on the bomb so the player has a larger challege to understand what happens.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045793254', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1491078986}
review:
Good idea with too little content.
Guz explained it in more detail:

[quote=Guz]Great idea for a game, diffusing Bombs Old school with cliping wires and pressing switches. It's nicely polished as well, but it's lacking content. I think the average person will be done in less than an hour.

While playing the game you get the distinct feeling that the creators of the game didn't have a too firm grasp of the underlying concepts of logic gates or just plain electronics themselves. The OR Gate for example has a whole tutorial section, when it serves no function that a forked trace wouldn't have fullfiled in most cases. Also the last puzzle in the second to last section features a solution that is - in contrast to the rest of the game - physically impossible to create with real world electronics (a circuit that powers itself). 

The puzzle design is also somewhat lackluster, some puzzles are solved by just clipping all wires or switching all switches and many don't even have a way for you to accidently trigger the explosion prematurely.

The mechanical foundation on the other hand is very solid and if this ever gets workshop support i think the user generated content will make up for the way too easy and not well thought out puzzles included in the base game.[/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198029764783', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1585088462}
review:
This is a neat game.  It's a puzzle game that teaches you rudimentary electronics under the guise of diffusing bombs.  It starts off simple, with basic concepts like switches and wire cutting, then gradually introduces more complex things, like capacitors, push buttons, a few logic gates, etc...

If I had to come up with a complaint, it's too short.  I finished it in a little over an hour, but that was in one sitting, and I was engaged the whole time, considering the possible ramifications of each little button press, each wire cut.

Now that the complaint is out of the way, here's what I liked:
1:  I greatly enjoyed the core concept, solving puzzles to diffuse bombs, but then again, I'm probably slightly biased toward puzzle games.
2:  I liked the implementation, specifically, how they ramped up the complexity rather than just dumping stuff on you all at once.  The way I see it, it makes the game approachable.
3:  I don't know why, but I really got a kick out of the tension created by the two constraints you have to operate under:  you have to get the circuit to behave the way you want to in a short time limit (anywhere from 1 minute to 1 minute 30 seconds, and sometimes even 2 minutes) AND you can't mess up.  That, I think, was the bigger part of that equation, predicting that this wire I'm about to cut will diffuse the bomb, being wrong, and being greeted by the White Screen of 'Asploding.

If this game gets updated, and/or gets Workshop implemented, I think it'll really shine.

TL;DR - Kinda short, but a fun puzzle game.

review:
This one is really hard to recommend. The review is more "if" than actual review. But I think it has potential, so it gets a thumbs up (albeit a weak one).

Having played the demo, I was excited for a Zachtronics-like hard as nails freeform puzzler. This ain't it.
When you've done what feels like the tutorial, the game is over. That's 30 minutes to an hour, tops. 

But what is there is GOOD. Great, even. There's the basic building blocks of something brilliant in there. I want to support further development, and I hope that money helps make the game better.

If you're interested, there's a demo available on the game's website. If you like the mechanics and don't mind that you'll only get about twice as much time out of the game as you did the demo, I'd say buy it.

I really hope the developer decides to expand this. The concept is great, but there's no real challenge.

review:
拆弹队学院！

这是一款很标准的解密游戏，游戏很简单，随着游戏流程的推进，你也能获得一些电路的知识，但都不是很难（初中到高中左右的水平吧）。

游戏最为可贵的一点是，并没有为了增长游戏长度而刻意注水，整个壳子，UI，模型也都还比较漂亮。游玩的过程相当舒服。

虽然相对于游戏时间来说可能价格略显贵了，但我已经很久没看过这么轻松，又不需要体力性操作的解密了（典型反例是之前出的 Crazy Machine 3).
考虑到这款游戏也是出自只有两个人的小团队（Credit里面大部分位置就只有一个人），这样的效果还是相当不错的。希望大家支持一下开发者，也希望开发者以后能开发出更有挑战性的揭秘作品。

review:
I feel like I have to give this game a thumbs up because it's quite good and well-made in many ways. It's a logic puzzle game reminiscent of zachtronics games, based on circuitry and logic gates, where instead of being presented with a straight-up puzzle or being asked to produce a particular output, you have to disarm a bomb. It's quite good. It really eases you into it if you've never played such a game before, but it does throw in some clever tricks, and the sense of tension that goes along with a ticking bomb adds something to it. But it's too short.

I got through this entire game in 74 minutes, and I would say that despite having played similar games in the past I actually had a bit more trouble with it than I should have had. Even someone who's not a fan of logic games or puzzle games at all could get through the game at least as fast, probably faster.

The game desperately needs a level/bomb editor and workshop support. I really, really hope the dev uses some of the money they're getting from this to work on adding those things, along with some other additions: more mechanisms (particularly detonator types; I feel like there's some potential to get creative with bombs that need you to do things other than cut off the power or send power to the right places to defuse them) and possibly even stuff to build more than just bombs in an editor mode. With user content and Workshop support, this could be almost on par with some of the best games in the genre (i.e. zachtronics, pretty much) but more accessible to people who aren't puzzle/electrical engineering/programming nerds.

At CDN$ 6.62 (15% off), I was pretty disappointed. At the same time, let's be honest, some of my lunches cost more than $6.62, so I can't complain too much. It's not such an unfair price even if you can get more content for the same price in other games. But if the dev uses some of the money to add Workshop support and/or more content, I'll be more than satisfied.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984331181', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1491003319}
review:
A fiver gets you about an hour of quality puzzle gaming. The game itself is very well realised and fun to play as well as behaving somewhat realistically with the components- this game is a good way to learn how things work in a circuit, in a practical sense. Electrical engineers (budding and actual) have an advantage!

However Bomb Squad Academy is very short. If you're the type who wants both time and quality from your money then you may be dissapointed. However if you enjoy the idea of a realisitic(ish) circuit based puzzle game you should at least consider trying it out. The short play time really is the only criticism I can muster.

The game is crying out for level packs and steam workshop puzzles a la Portal 2, If it gets them then we have an indie gem on our hands.

Those without much of an interest in puzzle games would better spend their money elsewhere. However those with an interest in electronics (albiet at a slightly more than basic level), may want to look more closely at the game.

review:
[h1]Bomb Squad Academy - единственная "академия", которую я закончил и закончил так быстро![/h1]
BSA - головоломка, целью которой является предотвращение взрыва бомбы. В ней вам придется не только ванильно отрезать провода, но и нажимать всякие кнопочки и тумблеры, параллельно поглядывая на коммутаторы, как говорится, всех цветов.
В положительные качества данной игры можно записать аудиосопровожление - очень нагнетающие, подходит для обезвреживания всякой опасной фигни; незаспрайтованные провода - при отрезании красного или черного, провода делятся в месте пореза, ЧТО СОЗДАЕТ БОЛЬШУЮ РЕАЛИСТИЧНОСТЬ.
Однако, у такой очень хорошой и подающей надежды игры есть и минусы, которые очень тесно связаны друг с другом и выливаются один в другой, а именно продолжительность и отсутствие workshop-а. Пока что игра состоит из +/- 68 миссий которые, в среднем, проходятся за час. Получив сертификат и лицензию минера [spoiler](закончить игру)[/spoiler], хочится продолжить бравое дело, однако и увы, негде.
В итоге, игра получилась довольно таки занятной, но мало играбельной [spoiler]( в плане времени)[/spoiler]
Рекомендую дождаться, когда появиться workshop [spoiler]если же он появится[/spoiler], и уже тогда уже брать, а пока не стоит.

review:
The idea is great, and the execution too. But just when I started having fun, the game ended. Actually only the last bomb was actually hard. Okay, I know basic logical circuits, so none of the concept were new to me, but regardless, the game is lacking in content. It would be pure awesomeness if we had dozens of bombs like the last one. This way, the game feels like a tutorial for a future game.
I have to compare it with SpaceChem. In SC, I spent hours figuring out some of the puzzles and I still didn't finish it. Here, the puzzles work out quite quickly. Okay, there has to be some tension with bomb defusing, but give us more time and way more complex bombs. I'll anyways recommend the game, because in all other aspects, it's great. Especially if you're new to logic circuits. Also, if you like games from Zachtronics (Shenzhen, SpaceChem, Infinifactory) and such, you'll like this one too, but will probably also feel it's too easy/short. I would gladly pay double/triple the price for x3-4 of more complex bombs. If you want to learn digital logics, this will teach you the basics in a couple hours and it's probably one of the most entertaining tools to do so.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960277275', 'num_games_owned': 864, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1490770022}
review:
I don't usually write reviews for games, but I feel this game does deserve some feed back.

I honestly did have fun playing through the game, which took me about 50 minutes to complete all the levels. But was very disappointed when I completed the last level, I really wanted more.  In reflection after playing I feel like I did get my entertainment value for the price.  I would gladly come back and play more if more levels were created.  Disabling the power trace helper is a MUST for any experienced puzzler.

If you're fan of puzzles or logic games, I do recommend getting this game, it will take you less than an hour to complete, and will leave you wanting more.

[b]PROS[/b]:
[list]
 [*]I had fun!
 [*]Simple puzzle mechanics, but by no means a cake walk. I blew myself up on purpose and accidentally.
 [*]The beeping timers added a fun layer of stress.
 [*]Tutorials introduce the different components nicely (logic gates, capacitors, buttons...) and mix them together in interesting ways.
[/list]

[b]CONS[/b]:
[list]
 [*]Felt short, I was disappointed when I finished the game, I really wanted more!
 [*]No replayability after completing the game.
 [*]VERY minor graphical issue.  The whole bomb would scale down slightly when clicking on buttons.
[/list]

[b]WISH LIST[/b]:
[list]
 [*]More puzzles! I would come back and play more for harder puzzles.
 [*]Editor for community created content.
 [*]Would've liked to be able to rotate the bomb/board, that could lead to some interesting puzzles due with double sided boards.
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561197996694272', 'num_games_owned': 841, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 46, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1490764949}
review:
Basic electronic circuitry is fun, but I feel like there's not enough depth going on here. I made snip snip and click click with the bombs. A couple times they went boom. The boom wasn't very satisfying, so sad for that. I got a bit less than an hour of playtime out of it, and that felt like not enough. 

The game balances between simple layouts that allow for quick deduction of the implications of a particular action ... and obfuscated layouts that try to hide the system from you and deny you a clear deductive path. Of course, the whole thing falls apart when you consider that a given level's board doesn't change between attempts. If you're willing to sit there spending your entire time working out the circuit ... sure you'll explode, but then you'll have a whole new countdown to keep solving the same puzzle. So they're not really a timed challenge.

I've been trying to pick up more quick puzzle games lately to vary my gameplay ... but I felt like this one was a dud.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009997705', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1490730635}
review:
J'ai franchement beaucoup aimé Bomb Squad Academy! Avouez que vous avez toujours voulu le couper ce satané fil rouge hein! Avec Bomb Squad Academy c'est enfin possible! Mais attention le résultat sera potentiellement explosif si vous n'avez pas planifié votre coup correctement!!

Le principe du jeu est assez simple: vous êtes devant un circuit électronique (simplifié!) avec un compte à rebours, lui même relié à de l'explosif! Le but est alors d'intéragir avec le circuit (par exemple en coupant un fil ou en manipulant un interrupteur) afin de rendre la bombe inopérante. Pour vous aider, le jeu affiche le trajet du courant, ce qui vous permet de de voir rapidement les conséquences de vos actions. (La visualisation du courant est désactivable dans les options, mais c'est à ne conseiller qu'aux forcenés!)

La progressivité est vraiment très bonne, chaque composant de circuit est présenté dans un tutorial où il est le centre de l'attention, et les concepts permettant de désamorcer une bombe sont appris au fur et à mesure des niveaux.
J'ai été agréablement surpris par le nombre de composants proposés, je ne m'attendais pas à retrouver condensateurs ou autres bascules dans l'arsenal utilisé par les poseurs de bombes (ou plutôt les "instructeurs" de l'académie). Cela change des jeux qui n'utilisent principalement que des classiques portes logiques "ET", "OU" etc.

Les concepts utilisés dans les bombes sont vraiment très sympas, l'interface est super inuitive et on ne peut pas s'empêcher de sourire lorsqu'on découvre un piège tendu dans un circuit de bombe, que ce soit au moment où on l'évite (sourire de victoire) ou quand on tombe dedans (la réalisation qu'on s'est fait duper!)

Point important: le jeu n'est qu'en anglais (pour l'instant?) mais cela ne gêne vraiment en rien la compréhension étant donné que le jeu nous fait tout apprendre par la manipulation directe et non pas par le discours (C'est la filière BAC PRO du déminage, pas la fac' :-) ).

Sinon, le jeu est encore un poil court pour les acharnés (ou les programmeurs qui ont l'habitude de ces concepts), et si vous vous sentez visés par la catégorie, n'hésitez pas à désactiver la visualisation du trajet du courant dans les options, ça crée réellement un challenge supplémentaire !! Mais quoi qu'il en soit, j'espère (et je pense!) que des niveaux supplémentaires (ou un éditeur permettant le partage de niveaux sur Steam?) seront bientôt proposés par les développeurs.

En conclusion: les quelques euros que m'a coûté ce jeu ont été, je trouve, bien investis car j'ai pris beaucoup de plaisir à y jouer. L'expérience de jeu est vraiment sympa et la variété des briques de bases est clairement rafraîchissante! Il ne manque qu'un peu du contenu additionnel pour combler l'insatiable démineur que je suis devenu!!

review:
The game itself is fun, but the puzzles are not very challenging. I finished it in 66 minutes and that is with replaying a few levels when I accidentally hit "replay" because I was trying to hit "Next level" prematurely.

At the current pricepoint you have to judge by yourself whether it's worth it to you. If you are a coder, it will probably be too easy for you.

For me, it's a bit too expensive for the amount of content and the difficulty. Also, there's no replay value whatsoever. With more (harder) content, the game could be a blast. This desperately needs workshop support or more/better levels. However, I did have fun and that's the point.

Tip for the devs: Turn current flow indicators off by default and enable them only in an "easy" mode.

review:
This is a perfect example of gameplay first with the added benefit of being brilliantly designed and superbly implemented; Oh and its jolly good fun to play too!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GdaEpfg8DK8

There are in the region of 70 levels split into 7 stages (and one bonus mixed round), and at each stage the components and complexity increase.

The simulated stress as the clock counts down to your imminent doom gets the blood pumping and should you fail to save the populous in time, there is that added injection of humour to make things seem alright again.

Excellent design of the boards, nice twists to design and the components and I am only half way through. This is as challenging as it is fun, the perfect balance.

Can't wait to see some DLC and new features!

First Impression gameplay: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uf1iD651KqY&index=30&t=1s&list=PL0ChqurHdrD4GDyzfEWF1egV0jL1CVSbq

This game is just booming with explosive fun.  
I was worried it would be a dud, but its just bursting with great gameplay.
Defusing these bombs was a blast.
I'll probably get a lot of fallout from these puns, but I just could not re-fuse!
Some people may believe there is not mush-room for puns in a review, but I was hoping to make an impact.

On a more serious note, this is a pretty good game overall.  The game starts with solving simple circuit problems.  Your objective is to sent current down a "diffuse" path, while avoiding the detonate path.  Some bombs require you to cut power to the detonator altogether.  It starts with simple rocker switches, progresses to cutting wires, and ramps up to "AND" gates from there.  Each section adds a new mechanic on top of what you learned in previous sections.  On top of all that, the bomb steadily counts down until detonation (you can increase time allowed in options if you are struggling).

[h1]PROS[/h1]
-Very fun gameplay
-Great soundtrack
-Graphics are very appealing and fit this genre
-The difficulty ramped up at a good rate as I progessed throughout the levels
-The game gives you a fair amount of time to defuse on each level
-Defuse mechanics are fun and can even teach about simple circuitry
-I enjoyed the little comments you receive when you fail and blow up the bomb 
-Priced fairly
-Did not encounter any bugs or glitches

[h1]CONS[/h1]
-Would have been nice to be able to rotate the bomb around like in "Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes"
-Wish the game was longer, beat it in about an hour and a half or so
